update.description:
ODE has a tendency to output NaN or inf values.

Added math functions to fix nan values, and applied these to ODEJoint value accessors.
update.title: Added fixnan functions

update.description:
ODE has a tendency to output NaN or inf values.

Added math functions to fix nan values, and applied these to ODEJoint value accessors.
update.title: Added fixnan functions

content.raw:
In general NaN's should be prevented or handled immediately. A NaN should never come out of a library. This is especially true when using accessor functions that involve no input from the user. NaN's have unexpected behavior when propagated through a system. We also cannot fix all the other libraries that Gazebo depends on in order to handle NaNs.

Nan's say that some mathematical operation was invalid. This is fine, but ODE should do something useful with that information when a NaN first appears. It's at that point when ODE can generate a meaningful error. In this case, a NaN from an a joint accessor tells us nothing about what went wrong.

A crash is worse than silently fixing a NaN. Gazebo has a bad reputation of crashing, we should actively fix that reputation. Since we have no information about what caused the NaN, there is nothing much we can do expect fix it as best we can to prevent a crash. 

I would also like to track down NaN sources. I believe joint accessor functions is not the correct location to put `if` checks. A better approach is to write a centralized physics checker. This approach will be more efficient, less duplicate code, and much easier to enable/disable. To this end, I have created a issue #891 to add this feature to Gazebo.
content.html:
In general NaN's should be prevented or handled immediately. A NaN should never come out of a library. This is especially true when using accessor functions that involve no input from the user. NaN's have unexpected behavior when propagated through a system. We also cannot fix all the other libraries that Gazebo depends on in order to handle NaNs.

Nan's say that some mathematical operation was invalid. This is fine, but ODE should do something useful with that information when a NaN first appears. It's at that point when ODE can generate a meaningful error. In this case, a NaN from an a joint accessor tells us nothing about what went wrong.

A crash is worse than silently fixing a NaN. Gazebo has a bad reputation of crashing, we should actively fix that reputation. Since we have no information about what caused the NaN, there is nothing much we can do expect fix it as best we can to prevent a crash.

I would also like to track down NaN sources. I believe joint accessor functions is not the correct location to put if checks. A better approach is to write a centralized physics checker. This approach will be more efficient, less duplicate code, and much easier to enable/disable. To this end, I have created a issue #891 to add this feature to Gazebo.

content.raw:
I am under the impression that In general NaN's should not cause codes to crash. NaN's normally simply propagate and fill simulation state data with useless NaN's. If code is crashing due to NaN states (e.g. NaN pose, velocity, etc), if possible we should try to identify and fix codes that crashes from NaN's instead.  Is there an example of a Gazebo crash caused by NaN?

Secondly, replacing NaN's silently with 0's will make it hard to debug actual errors in simulation, and may cause strange simulation results.  0 might not always be the "right fix" for NaN.  For example, if a NaN was caused by overflow, maybe we should replace it with the largest float or double representation per architecture.  On the other hand, if a NaN was caused by improper trigonometric function domain (e.g. asin(1.00001)), then fixnan should return something close to pi/2.

Lastly, to help track down sources of NaN's, I really like the idea of having NaN detectors around that stops simulation when NaN's happen, and gives user option to restart or reset simulation states after modifying simulation parameters (e.g. time step size, stiffness, etc.).  Given NaN's are not only caused by bugs, but can also be caused by poorly constructed simulation model or systems, often times the "fix" is user model parameter adjustment.
content.html:
I am under the impression that In general NaN's should not cause codes to crash. NaN's normally simply propagate and fill simulation state data with useless NaN's. If code is crashing due to NaN states (e.g. NaN pose, velocity, etc), if possible we should try to identify and fix codes that crashes from NaN's instead. Is there an example of a Gazebo crash caused by NaN?

Secondly, replacing NaN's silently with 0's will make it hard to debug actual errors in simulation, and may cause strange simulation results. 0 might not always be the "right fix" for NaN. For example, if a NaN was caused by overflow, maybe we should replace it with the largest float or double representation per architecture. On the other hand, if a NaN was caused by improper trigonometric function domain (e.g. asin(1.00001)), then fixnan should return something close to pi/2.

Lastly, to help track down sources of NaN's, I really like the idea of having NaN detectors around that stops simulation when NaN's happen, and gives user option to restart or reset simulation states after modifying simulation parameters (e.g. time step size, stiffness, etc.). Given NaN's are not only caused by bugs, but can also be caused by poorly constructed simulation model or systems, often times the "fix" is user model parameter adjustment.

content.raw:
That is a good question. I haven't checked. I think we are out of date from the latest ODE.

I'll write a test for this first.
content.html:
That is a good question. I haven't checked. I think we are out of date from the latest ODE.

I'll write a test for this first.

content.raw:
Oh, I did not know that is a bug in ODE what is causing problems to gazebo. I thought that was a bad use of ODE coming by our code or by user code/configuration which was making things to crash. Indeed there is no point in knowing that there is a known bug in ODE.

BTW, has been reported to ODE upstream? fixed in any particular version?
content.html:
Oh, I did not know that is a bug in ODE what is causing problems to gazebo. I thought that was a bad use of ODE coming by our code or by user code/configuration which was making things to crash. Indeed there is no point in knowing that there is a known bug in ODE.

BTW, has been reported to ODE upstream? fixed in any particular version?

content.raw:
Gazebo should never crash. This pull requests prevents a bug in ODE from crashing Gazebo.

Adding ASSERTS will just re-confirm that there is a bug in ODE. I could see the value in adding ASSERTS if we also go into ODE and fix the root of the problem.
content.html:
Gazebo should never crash. This pull requests prevents a bug in ODE from crashing Gazebo.

Adding ASSERTS will just re-confirm that there is a bug in ODE. I could see the value in adding ASSERTS if we also go into ODE and fix the root of the problem.

content.raw:
My 0.02€:

If the nan comes from the user, we should raise a warning, agree, even an error, but the message should be clear enough to inform the user about it (and ask him/her to fix it), specially if changing nan by a default value will affect the expected behavior. Not sure if this can be done in this case.

If the nan comes from internal component of gazebo, I would say that we should make it to crash while being in development phase (fail fast) and if fixing it generates a heavy unexpected behavior to the user, make it to exit with a clear message about submitting a bug, fix it as soon as possible and make a patch release. I like the idea of the ASSERTS in the case that we want to keep it running for debian package users.
content.html:
My 0.02€:

If the nan comes from the user, we should raise a warning, agree, even an error, but the message should be clear enough to inform the user about it (and ask him/her to fix it), specially if changing nan by a default value will affect the expected behavior. Not sure if this can be done in this case.

If the nan comes from internal component of gazebo, I would say that we should make it to crash while being in development phase (fail fast) and if fixing it generates a heavy unexpected behavior to the user, make it to exit with a clear message about submitting a bug, fix it as soon as possible and make a patch release. I like the idea of the ASSERTS in the case that we want to keep it running for debian package users.

content.raw:
No, I don't have any suggested improvements. Console messages can be hard to interpret, and they can quickly swamp the screen, so that's not the the best way.

I just wanted to talk about the strategy. Your comment addresses that.
content.html:
No, I don't have any suggested improvements. Console messages can be hard to interpret, and they can quickly swamp the screen, so that's not the the best way.

I just wanted to talk about the strategy. Your comment addresses that.

content.raw:
If the nan's come from the user, then we should raise a warning.

If the nan's come from some internal component of gazebo, then we should fix it and prevent a crash.

Do you have a suggestion for a message? We could try it, but historically any ambiguous warning message is quickly ignored or petitioned for removal.
content.html:
If the nan's come from the user, then we should raise a warning.

If the nan's come from some internal component of gazebo, then we should fix it and prevent a crash.

Do you have a suggestion for a message? We could try it, but historically any ambiguous warning message is quickly ignored or petitioned for removal.

content.raw:
Rhetorical question, largely to myself: should we be silently fixing nan's? It's good to know when things are broken. A console message would be useful if it doesn't impact performance and doesn't flood the screen when something bad happens.

Alternatively, what about asserts? In release mode we silently fix, in debug mode we catch the error.
content.html:
Rhetorical question, largely to myself: should we be silently fixing nan's? It's good to know when things are broken. A console message would be useful if it doesn't impact performance and doesn't flood the screen when something bad happens.

Alternatively, what about asserts? In release mode we silently fix, in debug mode we catch the error.
